issue.title: [taskchampion] Drop old versions on the sync server

labels.name: taskchampion
labels.description: Related specifically to taskchampion (and probably in Rust)

labels.name: rust
labels.description: Pull requests that update Rust code

comment.body:
Apologies for the wait while I found some time to consider this.

I think this sounds like a good model! Getting version timestamps from the `Date` header sounds good, but could also just use its local clock. I see a conceptual advantage to trusting the client though!

We could support this for the cloud-storage-backed model, too, by for example storing each replica's latest version in an object named `replica/<replica-uuid>/latest-version`. Then listing the replicas is just listing objects matching `replica/*` and deleting a replica is just deleting its `latest-version` object. I think we could use the object timestamp for version objects (`version/<uuid>`) as the version timestamp, or if necessary store an additional object containing the datestamp (`version/<uuid>/datestamp`).

Anyway, this is all just thinking about how this fits into other ideas. The proposal sounds good :)

issue.title: Add xtask msrv
issue.body:
#### Description

Adds a placeholder function for xtask called msrv with arguments (x,y) that starts work on [taskwarrior issue 3142](https://github.com/GothenburgBitFactory/taskwarrior/issues/3142): Automate synchronization of MSRV

#### Additional information...

- [x] I added placeholder function with 'hello world' and x,y parameter output.

- [x] I ran `cargo run msrv arg1 arg2` to confirm function is called and outputs as expected

- [x] I ran cargo test to confirm no warnings or errors

comment.body:
I think you have that correct! 

[Here](https://github.com/taskcluster/taskcluster/blob/fa5cc1ae21600f63c74fb0a99fc6da2f5667ea99/infrastructure/tooling/src/release/tasks.js#L135-L192) is an example of doing something similar, but in JS. This code writes out a new version number in a bunch of places. The `modifyRepoFile` method reads a file, calls a function with the content, then writes the result back to the file. As you can see, each file has a special way of replacing the content, that _only_ matches the place to change the value, and not anywhere else. Those have needed a bit of a tweak now and then, but have been pretty reliable. In my memory, some of them used a comment to help find the right place to modify, but that appears not to be the case!

Anyway, within Taskwarrior, as long as we can be pretty confident that only the correct value will be changed, and other parts of the file won't be accidentally modified, any kind of replacement strategy is fine.

comment.body: Pushed a commit to fix clippy issues, but still working on functionality to update file contents (instead of just file comments). (Had much less time this week).

issue.title: rc._forcecolor=on does not work with `watch`
issue.body:
Force-enabling the use of colors on the terminal works fine when piping the task output to `less -R` like in the following case:

```
task  rc._forcecolor=on   | less -R
```

However, wrapping the same command with `watch --color` doesn't enable the coloring of the tasks:

```
watch  --color task  rc._forcecolor=on
```

On the other hand combining `ls --color` with `watch --color` seems to work fine:

```
watch  --color ls --color
```

### Output of `task diag`

```
task 2.6.2
   Platform: Linux

Compiler
    Version: 9.4.0
       Caps: +stdc +stdc_hosted +LP64 +c8 +i32 +l64 +vp64 +time_t64
 Compliance: C++17

Build Features
     Commit: 0a558ef7c
      CMake: 3.23.0-rc2
    libuuid: libuuid + uuid_unparse_lower
  libgnutls: 3.6.13
 Build type:

Configuration
       File: /home/berger/.taskrc (found), 3971 bytes, mode 100664
       Data: /home/berger/.task (found), dir, mode 40775
    Locking: Enabled
         GC: Enabled
    $EDITOR: nvim
     Server:
         CA: not found
Certificate: not found
        Key: not found
      Trust: strict
    Ciphers: NORMAL
      Creds:

Hooks
     System: Enabled
   Location: /home/berger/.task/hooks
             (-none-)

Tests
   Terminal: 161x41
       Dups: Scanned 10481 tasks for duplicate UUIDs:
             No duplicates found
 Broken ref: Scanned 10481 tasks for broken references:
             No broken references found

```

issue.title: Impossible to add a recurring task with hooks in place
issue.body:
I am sorry if I am not providing much details but this is the nth bug I am reporting with hooks.

I do not mean anything by that comment, I am grateful for this software, and I understand that maintainers have more important things to do, just giving some context.

I have no idea how to debug this one. The biggest problem, is that when adding a recurring task with hooks in place, I do not get an error, just hanging tw. C-C interrupts the process, but running `task` again hangs until interrupting it again. This time I get an error traceback that complains about lines from the hooks.

I tried to comment out the entire content of the on-add hook, and then it complains about the content of the on-modify hooks !
Adding the recurring task with `rc.hooks=off` does not change anything which is weird. 
I tried adding a condition at the beginning of my hooks to exit(0) if the task has the recurring status; no difference.

The only thing allowing me to add recurring tasks is to delete all hooks from the hook folder.

C-C interrupts the process, but running `task` again hangs until interrupting it again. This time I get an error traceback that complains about lines from the hooks.

comment.body:
Using a statement as follows allowed me to exit the hook script: `if "recur" in new_task`. So I guess the bug was not coming from the recurring template task being created, but the first instance. 
Why this instance is causing a bug, I have no idea.

comment.body:
thanks to my colleague - we found lost color.

watch strips not-ANSI colors.
change taskwarrior color scheme returns colors in task-list in watch.

issue.title: Large values in `Scheduled` column break formatting in `next` report
issue.body:
# How to reproduce

* Have a task list where the report fills out the screen
* Add a `scheduled:someday` to one of the reports (keep it at the front with `+next`)
* -> Table formatting breaks

## Example
![image](https://github.com/GothenburgBitFactory/taskwarrior/assets/936176/3684971f-f005-43bb-a9d1-9d25cae7b0d9)
Task 117 on the picture has its urgency score moved into the next row.

task diag:
```

   Platform: Linux

Compiler
    Version: 7.5.0
       Caps: +stdc +stdc_hosted +LP64 +c8 +i32 +l64 +vp64 +time_t64

Hooks

Tests

       Dups: Scanned 803 tasks for duplicate UUIDs:
             Found duplicate 431cc222-4f33-4f88-b0f7-5a1eb4344fe1
```

issue.title: Add xtask msrv
issue.body:
#### Description

Adds a placeholder function for xtask called msrv with arguments (x,y) that starts work on [taskwarrior issue 3142](https://github.com/GothenburgBitFactory/taskwarrior/issues/3142): Automate synchronization of MSRV

#### Additional information...

- [x] I added placeholder function with 'hello world' and x,y parameter output.

- [x] I ran `cargo run msrv arg1 arg2` to confirm function is called and outputs as expected

- [x] I ran cargo test to confirm no warnings or errors

comment.body:
Thanks for the feedback @djmitche . I had incorrectly understood and assumed that the intent was to update **comments** in files that specify the MSRV to be used, therefore my approach was to look for comments in files that contained `MSRV` and replace those comments with the X.Y argument.

Instead, it sounds like the intent is to update any given configuration file's specifications. So, similar to what you wrote above, in `checks.yml` where the following appears...

```yaml
      - uses: actions-rs/toolchain@v1
        with:
          # Same as the MSRV in rust-tests.yml
          toolchain: "1.64"
```

...the version in the line ```toolchain: "1.64"``` should be updated to whatever X.Y is passed as an argument to xtask msrv.

If that is the case, then my approach would be to look for an older X.Y and update it with the new X.Y where `MSRV` (and similar phrases) appears on the same line, or the preceding line.

Do I have that correct?
The clippy lint here is pointing out that `file_extension` is overwritten before it is read in every codepath, so it doesn't need to be initialized here. Same thing below for `comment_glyph`.

pull_request.title: Add xtask msrv
pull_request.body:
#### Description

Adds a placeholder function for xtask called msrv with arguments (x,y) that starts work on [taskwarrior issue 3142](https://github.com/GothenburgBitFactory/taskwarrior/issues/3142): Automate synchronization of MSRV

#### Additional information...

- [x] I added placeholder function with 'hello world' and x,y parameter output.

- [x] I ran `cargo run msrv arg1 arg2` to confirm function is called and outputs as expected

- [x] I ran cargo test to confirm no warnings or errors

comment.body: This lint is pointing out that `if foo.is_some() { .. foo.unwrap() .. }` is better expressed as `if let Some(bar) = foo { .. bar .. }`.

pull_request.title: Add xtask msrv
pull_request.body:
#### Description

Adds a placeholder function for xtask called msrv with arguments (x,y) that starts work on [taskwarrior issue 3142](https://github.com/GothenburgBitFactory/taskwarrior/issues/3142): Automate synchronization of MSRV

#### Additional information...

- [x] I added placeholder function with 'hello world' and x,y parameter output.

- [x] I ran `cargo run msrv arg1 arg2` to confirm function is called and outputs as expected

- [x] I ran cargo test to confirm no warnings or errors

review.body:
There are a few clippy checks below that I've highlighted. But, I'm a bit confused about what this is doing right now. It looks like, in a Rust file for example, it would look for a line like

```rust
    let x = y; // MSRV = 1.59
```
and if found turn that into
```rust
// MSRV = 1.60
    let x = y; // MSRV = 1.59
```

Maybe I can give a clearer description of how this typically works in other projects. Somewhere in the middle of ``, there appears

```yaml
      - uses: actions-rs/toolchain@v1
        with:
          toolchain: "1.64" # MSRV - update with 'cargo xtask msrv' 
          override: true
```
(I've added the comment; you can do the same in the PR)

So, to update that MSRV:
 * look for a line ending with `# MSRV update with 'cargo xtask msrv'`
 * if not found, output the existing line
 * if found, replace `[0-9]\.[0-9]{2,}` with the new version within the line and output it.

Does that make more sense?

This might be easier to test if you factor out the "replace the MSRV" operation into a function that operates on a string. Then the `msrv` function can read the file content to a string, call the replacement function, and write the result back out. And tests can just provide a test string to the replacement function.

pull_request.body:
#### Description

Adds a placeholder function for xtask called msrv with arguments (x,y) that starts work on [taskwarrior issue 3142](https://github.com/GothenburgBitFactory/taskwarrior/issues/3142): Automate synchronization of MSRV

- [x] I ran `cargo run msrv arg1 arg2` to confirm function is called and outputs as expected

review.body:
There are a few clippy checks below that I've highlighted. But, I'm a bit confused about what this is doing right now. It looks like, in a Rust file for example, it would look for a line like

```rust
    let x = y; // MSRV = 1.59
```
and if found turn that into
```rust
// MSRV = 1.60
    let x = y; // MSRV = 1.59
```

Maybe I can give a clearer description of how this typically works in other projects. Somewhere in the middle of ``, there appears

```yaml
      - uses: actions-rs/toolchain@v1
        with:
          toolchain: "1.64" # MSRV - update with 'cargo xtask msrv' 
          override: true
```
(I've added the comment; you can do the same in the PR)

So, to update that MSRV:
 * look for a line ending with `# MSRV update with 'cargo xtask msrv'`
 * if not found, output the existing line
 * if found, replace `[0-9]\.[0-9]{2,}` with the new version within the line and output it.

Does that make more sense?

This might be easier to test if you factor out the "replace the MSRV" operation into a function that operates on a string. Then the `msrv` function can read the file content to a string, call the replacement function, and write the result back out. And tests can just provide a test string to the replacement function.
